title: Delhi Air Quality:PMO Asks Punjab, Haryana To Crackdown On Stubble Burning As Delhi Registers Seasons' Worst Air Quality
text:
The Prime Minister’s Office (PMO) has asked Punjab and Haryana to crack down on stubble burning in their respective states for the next three weeks as the national capital is witnessing a sharp decline in the air quality.

According to reports, some 13 hotspots along the Punjab-Haryana border have been identified from where maximum cases of crop fires have been detected.

AP/ REPRESENTATIONAL IMAGE

Stating that the next three weeks will be crucial in controlling air quality spikes, the states have been asked to take every measure possible to reduce stubble burning and initiate maximum crackdown in the hotspots.

The stubble burning coupled with bursting of firecrackers during Diwali and adverse weather conditions are likely to make the already toxic air quality even worse in the next few days.

According to C K Mishra, secretary, MoEF, the air quality in the national capital could be severely affected from October 27 to November 4 due to stubble burning and firecrackers.

Delhi's air quality has already crossed the 300 mark in the past few days and is likely to remain the same before it turns severe.

AP

An AQI between 0 and 50 is considered ‘good’, 51 and 100 ‘satisfactory’, 101 and 200 ‘moderate’, 201 and 300 ‘poor’, 301 and 400 ‘very poor’, and 401 and 500 ‘severe’.

Other than asking neighbouring states to crackdown on stubble burning the PMO has also directed the Delhi government and local bodies as well to carry out sprinkling of water, mechanised sweeping and crackdown on dust pollution at the local ward level.
